published.fact_text: On 21 December 1968, Apollo 8 became the first crewed spacecraft to leave Earth’s orbit and head for the Moon, launching from Kennedy Space Center into the unknown. Its crew would soon become the first humans to witness an Earthrise over another world.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 2020, Jupiter and Saturn aligned in an unusually close great conjunction, appearing just 0.1° apart in the night sky. For many observers, it was the closest visible meeting of these giant planets since the early 17th century.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1872, HMS Challenger left Portsmouth on a four-year voyage that essentially founded modern oceanography. Its crew mapped vast stretches of the seafloor, discovered thousands of species, and revealed that the deep ocean was anything but lifeless.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1946, the Nankai megathrust segment off Japan ruptured in an Mw 8.1 earthquake, unleashing a devastating tsunami. The disaster spurred decades of research into subduction zones and early-warning systems that still protect coastal communities today.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1937, Disney’s Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs premiered in Los Angeles, becoming the first feature-length cel-animated film with sound and color. It proved that animation could tell long, emotionally rich stories and reshaped cinema forever.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club

From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1934, Sergei Prokofiev’s suite Lieutenant Kijé premiered, based on music he wrote for a satirical Soviet film about an officer who never existed. The piece’s haunting melodies, especially the famous “Troika,” outlived the film and became classics on their own.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: A film-born orchestral suite with a vivid, almost cinematic feel aligns with an episode steeped in neo-classical, soundtrack-like atmospheres.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1879, Henrik Ibsen’s play A Doll’s House premiered in Copenhagen, shocking audiences with its portrayal of a woman walking out on her marriage. It helped ignite modern drama and debates on gender equality that still echo today.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1844, the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers opened their cooperative store, selling basic goods at fair prices. Their principles of democratic ownership and shared profit became the template for cooperatives worldwide.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1620, the Mayflower Pilgrims landed near today’s Plymouth Rock, founding Plymouth Colony after a perilous Atlantic crossing. Their small community would loom large in later stories of American beginnings and migration.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1826, a group of settlers in Nacogdoches declared the short-lived Republic of Fredonia, sparking the Fredonian Rebellion against Mexican rule. Though quickly suppressed, it foreshadowed later conflicts that would reshape Texas.

episode.title: Morning Drops #13 - Demystifying Reggaeton

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1923, the United Kingdom and Nepal signed the Nepal–Britain Treaty, formally recognizing Nepal’s independence and sovereignty. It marked a rare moment when a Himalayan kingdom secured international status without being colonized.

episode.title: Morning Drops #26 - Endless Summer

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1361, Castilian forces defeated the Emirate of Granada at the Battle of Linuesa during the long Reconquista. The clash was one of many turning points in a centuries-long struggle that reshaped the cultural map of Iberia.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1598, Mapuche warriors led by cacique Pelentaru crushed Spanish forces in the Battle of Curalaba. Their victory sparked a long indigenous uprising that halted Spanish expansion in southern Chile for generations.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 69 AD, the Roman Senate declared Vespasian emperor, ending the chaotic Year of the Four Emperors. His reign restored stability and launched the Flavian dynasty after a year of coups and civil war.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1124, Honorius II was consecrated pope following the controversial overturning of Celestine II’s short-lived claim. His election highlighted the power struggles between factions in the medieval Church and the Holy Roman Empire.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.fact_text: On 21 December 1941, Thailand signed a Pact of Alliance with Japan during World War II, formally joining the Axis powers. The decision reshaped the country’s wartime role and its postwar negotiations with the Allies.
